title: Tuesday, 6th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hi. Good morning. Welcome. This is Markets Live, the thing with the stuff.

BE11:07am

It's easy for Bloomberg. They have a rotating quote of the day to chuck at terminal users.

BE11:07am

Here's today's.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

... lol they misspelt "news".

BE11:07am

We, however, must be more freeform.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

So here's a letter.

BE11:08am

BE11:08am

(Click this link to make readable: https://tinyurl.com/ybbu7m86 )

11:08 am
BE11:08am

It's from the Halifax, and it's to me.

BE11:08am

It tells me that, in 2009, I tried and failed to take £30 out of a borky cash machine.

BE11:09am

Six years later the Halifax was refunded. And just two years after that, I'm refunded.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which is fine, I guess. Mitigating circumstances.

BE11:09am

Because 2009 was tricky for banks! No one was sure where anyone else's cash was.

BE11:09am

I mean, RBS took £45m from us that year, and we're still not sure of its whereabouts.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

What I'd like to draw your attention to, though, is the interest rate.

BE11:10am

8%! Twice! Cracking!

BE11:10am

Except it's not, is it? Because the 8% is not annually compounded.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

It's an effective annual rate from each bank of about 2.2%. Before tax. For a period when inflation averaged 3%.

BE11:11am

That's fairly crappy compensation, right? For theft? Theft that's not even acknowledged for eight years?

BE11:11am

I know it's only £30, but still.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

It seems likely I needed that money to drink heavily.

BE11:11am

It was 2009. Drinking heavily felt like the only option.

BE11:11am

And the banks haven't rightfully compensated us for that either, come to think of it.

11:11 am
undefined
BE11:12am

Yes! @Dunoon, it's quiet.

BE11:12am

The news desk seems to have spent the past couple of hours discussing whether uninterruptible power supplies should have plugs.

11:12 am
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 590.50, down 1.5 (-0.25%), High: 595.00, Low: 590.00, Volume: 5.60m
BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-919a-1e14ce4af89b

BE11:14am

The head of British Airway’s parent company has insisted that human error, rather than overly aggressive cost-cutting, was the cause of the computer systems shutdown that left 75,000 BA passengers stranded on a holiday weekend and caused severe damage to the reputation of the UK’s flagship carrier.

Willie Walsh, chief executive of International Airlines Group, said an engineer had inadvertently switched off the power supply to one of the company data centres and it was then turned back on again in an uncontrolled fashion. An independent investigation would be carried out, he said.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Have I told you about the place I worked, a national newspaper, where the office cleaners would unplug the server for their vacuums most mornings and throw the website offline?

BE11:15am

I probably have. I've used all my stories on you lot already.

BE11:16am

Anyway, there's a continuing discussion about why IAG's tech issues have done absolutely nothing to its share price.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The answer is kinda dull: short term cost is negligible in the scheme of things, and long-term cost is beyond estimation but probably fine going by precedent.

BE11:20am

(@Super SWF: cripes! Thanks for that! I was entirely ignorant to the size of the GFC and that was in no way just a typo caused by my need to type this in realtime.)

BE11:20am

Let me head into some forecasts, just to reiterate the point.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Here's SocGen

BE11:23am

Going into FY17 we were sceptical on IAG’s trading outlook for the year.
However, all the network airlines are currently benefiting from a recovery
in demand and unit revenues. And while sterling weakness is inflating
BA’s fuel bill, it also stimulates UK inbound demand. At the 1Q stage, IAG
surprisingly guided for an increase in unit revenues from 2Q onwards. We
reflect that in double-digit rises our earnings forecasts and increase our
TP by 23% to 650p.

BE11:24am

From the end of last week, to be clear. Not this morning. Because no broker has bothered commenting on the plug-out-gate.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Improving unit revenues...
IAG became more optimistic on unit revenues when
presenting the 1Q figures. There had been no specific unit revenue guidance before, but in the 1Q presentation IAG guided for positive unit revenues in 2Q, implying a significant qoq trend improvement, as 1Q unit revenues were down 3.1%. Management also aims for positive unit revenues in FY17. We increase our forecast for underlying unit revenues (RASK ex currencies) from flat to +1%.

BE11:25am

...more important than BA’s IT outage
The IT outage at BA, causing significant disruptions of the flight schedule, might have a short-term negative effect, but we think the market will look through it. We expect one-off costs of up to €80m. However, further significant IT issues would definitely burden the sentiment for the stock.

BE11:25am

Our valuation is based on a target multiple of 5.5x adj. EV/EBITDAR 2017e.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

This is a modest premium to our target multiple for European peers (Lufthansa at 5x and Air France-KLM at 4.5x) and also in line with the historical average
for European flag carriers. We adjust the EV by the amount resulting from the
capitalisation of the operating leases (aircraft lease payments) by adding 8x the annual
lease charge to reflect the average lease term, in line with the methodology used by the company. Dominant short-term risks: on the downside negative news from the Brexit negotiations and/or a reoccurrence/worsening of the outages; on the upside, furtherimprovements in demand and unit revenues.

BE11:26am

(SuperSWF: Thumbs up )

undefined
11:26 am
BE11:26am

While on this general theme ..........

Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 511.59, down 12.41 (-2.37%), High: 523.50, Low: 511.50, Volume: 801.37k
BE11:27am

Under a certain amount of pressure ahead of next week's AGM.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Where the company doesn't need to look far for excuses to talk down guidance.

BE11:29am

The big one being London footfall, of course. You have to assume, with the mood still being a tad febrile, folk are unlikely to want to take a mortal risk just to visit Shrek Adventure.

BE11:29am

Panmure had a preview out a couple of days ago.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The AGM statement traditionally has no numbers but we expect YTD trading to be in line with management expectations. The trend of improving inbound visitations to Merlin’s London attractions should be holding, given strong hotel RevPAR/air traffic data and robust airport concession performance from the likes of SSP Group/The Restaurant Group. Terrorism concern remains elevated across gateaway cities (and the Drayton Manor tragedy may have taken the shine off UK performance) but Merlin’s portfolio is well diversified (greater than 70% profits ex-UK) and 2017 expectations feel well set as peak trading approaches, for £306m PBT. Share price strength has continued and Merlin’s valuation now (rightly) sits towards the top of the peer group, trading on 12.8x 2017 EV/EBITDA.

BE11:30am

Oh, and while we're here .....

BE11:30am

Barclays' latest spend trend thing's out.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

It's pretty bad.

BE11:30am

Consumer spending growth was 2.8% y/y in May, according to the latest Barclaycard data, well below the three-month average of 4.3%.

BE11:31am

That's for April 23 to May 20, which includes the bank holiday.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And yes, I know, retailers blaming the weather. But online vs high street does point to rain.

BE11:31am

BE11:31am

The weakness seems largely related to poor in-store sales, which were negative for the first time in 10 months. In-store spending growth was -1.3% in May, well below the 3-month average (0.7%). Online spending continued its double-digit growth at 15.0%, in line with the 3-month average (15.0%). The divergence between the two is close to the highest seen over the last 5 years.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Weather could be partially responsible for negative In-store growth: Poor weather during the period may be partially responsible, with more rainfall and less sunshine in England than May 2016. Some of the categories that saw poorer growth this month were against tough comps from May 2016, such as Clothing, Household, and Department Stores. We have also seen fuel price growth starting to ease over the last few months, bringing spending growth on petrol down with it. Lastly, the weak numbers are at odds with consumer confidence, which picked up modestly in May.

undefined
BE11:33am

And so, to AO World.

11:33 am
AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 136.40, down 8.6 (-5.93%), High: 137.00, Low: 130.00, Volume: 269.08k
BE11:33am

UK growth slowing

BE11:33am

Outlook week.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

2018 slowdown is now going to be "significant"

BE11:34am

"challenging trading has continued into start of new year"

BE11:34am

Consensus was on for 18% growth in 2018, though the recent share price performance makes that look a bit stale.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

JP Morgan Caz can summarise the figures.

BE11:35am

AO World has reported FY 17 results in-line with guidance provided at the
group’s pre-close update and management is pleased with the strategic
progress achieved in the year. Whilst AO has reassured that it expects FY
18 group sales and profits to fall within the range of market expectations,
it has commented cautiously on expected Q1 growth in the UK given both
the challenging trading environment and tough comparatives. Given this
cautious tone on current trading, we expect the shares to open lower. With
the stock trading close to our target price, we retain our Neutral rating,
although continue to recommend caution in the short term ahead of clearer
visibility on the UK consumer outlook.

BE11:35am

FY 17 results broadly in-line with expectations. In-line with guidance
at the pre-close stage, AO increased FY 17 UK revenue by 12.7%.
Within this AO.com sales were +14.5% (JPMe +16%). We estimate that
UK revenue and AO.com growth in Q4 was +7% and +9%, respectively.
UK EBITDA of £24.4m (JPMe £23.4m) was +42% yoy and represented
a margin of 3.9% (+80bps yoy). Including European losses, group
EBITDA of £-2.1m was in-line with guidance for £-2.4m to flat, albeit
towards the bottom end of the range (JPMe £-1.5m). AO ended the year
with net cash of £12m, although to be clear this does not include
proceeds from the recent £50m capital raise.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Cautious tone on UK current trading... Whilst AO continues to win
share in the UK, the trading environment in the UK remains challenging
in the new financial year. Combined with tough comparatives (post the
spike in housing transactions in March 2016 ahead of stamp duty
changes), management expects the UK Q1 18 growth rate to “slow
significantly year on year” (i.e. relative to +7% in Q4 17). We note that
comps ease as the year progresses and we leave our FY 18 UK revenue
growth forecast of +9% unchanged. Within this, we forecast AO.com
+12% (previously +13%).

BE11:37am

Shore Cap also.

BE11:37am

Sales in the UK grew 12.7% to £629.7m, underpinned by a 14.5% uplift in own website revenue. Third party revenues continue to regress at a high single digit rate, as AO's proprietary brand continues to gain traction with the consumer, during a period when management has stepped up marketing efforts. The UK business delivered an gross margin enhancement of 140 basis points to 21.2% and an adjusted EBITDA margin of 3.9%, with management commenting that sales in computing products are ahead of expectations thus far whilst product protection plans take up remains strong. We highlight further commentary from today's statement where management discussed significant inflationary pressures during CY2016. AO experienced between 10-15% price increases from suppliers in its chosen product categories.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

What to start with today?

BE11:37am

The group closed the period with a net cash position of £12.0m with actual cash decreasing by c£4m and borrowing increasing during the year to £17.4m from £8.0m. However the balance sheet has since been bolstered by a £50m equity raise via a share placing, post balance sheet date.

With the shares trading in excess of 55x EV/EBITDA for FY2019, the market appears to be factoring in a significant premium on the valuation of the business. As we have outlined recently, AO has a strong logistics capability with a slick customer facing web experience, however we do not believe this amounts to a compelling competitive point of difference in the electricals market.

Progression in Europe is key to investment case of this business and we await to see if execution emerges. Given the current rating and our concerns about the model, we reiterate our SELL recommendation.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:41am

I was going to go through the AO World argument about the huge money needing to be spent on marketing for a purchase that's twice a decade at most for the majority of customers, and which is increasingly competitive and price sensitive due to John Lewis creeping across the country and Curry's getting slightly less bad.

BE11:41am

But halfway through typing it I found myself bored, so I won't.

BE11:41am

What else?

11:41 am
BE11:41am

There's Burberry, I guess.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,769, down 41 (-2.27%), High: 1,778, Low: 1,752, Volume: 743.02k
BE11:42am

HSBC unimpressed. Too much margin preservation, no growth.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

And Gobbetti's going to have to figure out a plan, because that's not a plan.

BE11:43am

After delivering GBP20m in cost savings for FY March 2017, Burberry is on track for GBP50m this year and GBP100m next. Initiatives should also shave off 80bp the tax rate. The recently signed Beauty deal with Coty has been approved and will bump up profits. A new buyback program corresponding to 4% of the stock’s market cap has also been approved. All in, every shareholder-
friendly initiative seems to have been looked at to enable Burberry shares to be protected in the absence of what, in our view, would be the only real solid booster: a sustainable rebound in sales growth.

BE11:43am

Some brave new choices may be needed for the long term. The US seems to be the Achilles’ heel for many department store-heavy brands. Burberry does 30% of its sales at wholesale in the US, and within retail sales, we think likely more than a third are in outlets. Whether Marco Gobbetti, acting CEO as of early July, will be willing to
make the tough, but in our view necessary, re-set of the distribution footprint is still a question mark. We also believe that the group needs new life in terms of design and merchandising and the jury is out on whether the 100% dedication of Christopher Bailey on deign and a few external hires can suffice. Finally, the luxury sector’s challenge on “retail excellence” is one that Burberry must execute on to hope increasing sales densities and eventually margins more forcefully. On the repositioning journey, there could be hiccups before successes.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

c13% downside after our TP cut. Q4 (March 2017) was disappointing – only 2% retail like for like growth despite easier comps – both in absolute terms and relative to the likes of Gucci or Louis Vuitton. Burberry’s new management team could lead to a boost in sales but that could take a while. We lower our TP to 1,580p (from 1,630p) on the back of our EPS cut: -8% for FY March 2018 and -6% for FY March 2019 to reflect the Q4 sales miss and the FX’s adverse move (GBP strength against USD since we last published). This TP cut together with the 17% share price re-bound since the c1,550p level reached post the Q4 sales publication, leads to c13% downside. We downgrade to Reduce as we believe Burberry will underperform peers for longer than expected by the market. Even if our PBT estimates are in line with consensus, we think Burberry’s sales and earnings performance will not be sufficient
to sustain the stock’s demanding valuation (23.8x FY March 2018e and 21.1x FY March 2019e). Key upside risks include: GBL which bought 3% of the company increasing its stake further; and the perception that Burberry is a takeover target.

undefined
BE11:47am

...... sorry, was offscreen momentarily.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

That'd usually be the moment Paul would chuck up some Thundering Word or grump about some newly floated POS on Aim or whatever. But he's in Mozambique, so instead you get silence.

BE11:49am

Scanning down comments, it seems reasonable to recap the Qatar dispute.

BE11:50am

Sellside, generally, saying "this isn't a crisis".

11:50 am
BE11:50am

BE11:51am

That's via HSBC, which also says .......

BE11:51am

The standoff pits Qatar against Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt who claim
that Qatar supports “terrorism and extremism”, and thus poses a threat to their
national security. The dispute leaves Qatar isolated from its most powerful Arab
peers, and risks disrupting non-oil trade. However, it is unlikely to threaten economic
function or stability that centres on the emirate’s hydrocarbon sector, which generates 74% of Qatar’s fiscal receipts and 91% of its export earnings. Those revenues accrue from its sale of oil and LNG to Asian consumers, and are unlikely to be impacted by heightened regional tensions.
Any loss the economy feels must also be set against the wealth that Qatar accumulated during the pre-2014 hydrocarbon boom. The Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute put QIA holdings at USD335bn at end of 2016 and though the authorities do not disclose the value of their assets, Qatar has generated a cumulative current account surplus of USD339bn over the past 20 years, the equivalent of 200% of GDP and sufficient to offset the strain current uncertainty may bring.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

And Kepler, from the perspective of the oilers.

BE11:52am

Qatar is a relatively small oil producer inside OPEC, with production of 0.66mb/d, but it is also a major condensate and NGL producer (1.45mb/d including the 250kb/d of LPG and other liquids from Pearl-GTL). On the LNG markets, with 77m tonne yearly capacity, Qatar represented one-third of global LNG volumes last year. Finally, Qatar also exports some significant volumes of natural gas to the UAE (1.8bcf/d) and Oman (0.2bcf/d) via the Dolphin subsea pipeline with a capacity of 2bcf/d. Note that Egypt and the UAE also import some LNG volumes from Qatar.

BE11:53am

Qatar’s peninsula is de facto under embargo from regional neighbours, which could lead to a potential retaliation from Qatar by cutting gas pipeline supplies to the UAE/Oman (2bcf/d equivalent to 7.6m tonnes a year). We doubt Qatar will cut the Dolphin gas supplies to UAE/Oman as it will send a very negative signal to Qatar’s top LNG buyers. Press reports confirm yesterday that the Dolphin gas supply was still flowing.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

With net production of c. 327kboe/d in 2016 (9% of total production), Shell has the biggest exposure to Qatar within our coverage. Shell holds interests in two main assets: 100% in the Pearl GTL plant and a 30% working interest in Qatargas IV (7.8m tonnes a year). Total has 5.5% of its production in Qatar (134kboe/d in 2016) with several assets including a 10% stake in Qatargas I (9.9mtpa), 16.7% in the train V of Qatargas II (7.8mtpa), 24.5% in the Dolphin project, and 40% in the offshore Al Khali field (Total operator). Lastly, in 2016 Total signed an agreement to get a 30% stake in the Al-Shaheen offshore oil field (capacity 300kb/d, 100% basis) concession for a period of 25 years beginning July 14, 2017. BP, Repsol, OMV, Statoil, Galp have virtually no exposure to Qatar. Eni has an offtake agreement of 2.05m tonnes a year from Rasgas II Train 3.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,147, up 7.15 (+0.33%), High: 2,148, Low: 2,124, Volume: 1.65m
undefined
11:55 am
BE11:55am

............ otherwise ..................

BE11:56am

(@BT: I've no idea. If any lawyers want a % of my £30 they're welcome to fight the case for me.)

BE11:57am

(@Soundbuy: If I have anything I'll share,)

11:57 am
BE11:57am

EasyJet traffic stats?

BE11:57am

They're fine.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,357, up 13 (+0.97%), High: 1,367, Low: 1,334, Volume: 1.23m
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Here's Goodbody.

BE11:57am

easyJet: May traffic stats saw passenger up 9.5% yoy; this compares to April’s pax growth
of 11.7% and the combined March/April growth rate of 11.2%. Load factor was flat yoy at
91.5% on the back of the 9.5% growth in capacity. The surprise here was the faster capacity
growth as compared to the 8.7% seen in April (when all of the Easter trade was recognised).
On our current Q1 21.9m passenger and 23.8m seat forecasts, May’s outrun would leave the
residual June month only requiring 5% growth in passengers and 7% growth in capacity to
hit our targets. As such, we would likely lift our passenger forecast for June by 0.25m pax to
7.53m and our June seat capacity by 0.12m to 8m for a flat load factor at 94.1%. This is a
positive performance.

BE11:58am

Flew EasyJet twice last week. 90 minutes delayed on the way out, two hours delayed on the way back.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Kadhim flew EasyJet yesterday. 2.5hrs delayed on the way out.

BE11:59am

The total inability to take off at the time advertised doesn't really encourage me to fly EasyJet more regularly.

BE12:00pm

That seems to be the more interesting argument with regards cutting ground costs etc, rather than the British Airways one about plugs on servers. But news has to be on a timely hook, of course.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Ryanair, while we're here.

BE12:01pm

Ryanair: May traffic stats continued the strong trend with passengers up 10.6% yoy; this
compares to April’s pax growth of 13.7% and the combined March/April growth rate of
12.3%. Load factor was up 1ppt to 95% on the back of 9.4% growth in capacity. On our
current Q1 35.5m passenger forecast (+13.8%), this would leave the residual June month
requiring 17% growth to hit our target, suggesting we may have to trim our number back by
0.5m for the month to 11.9m for 12% growth yoy. At the same time we will likely take 1m
seats off our current number. While we remain comfortable with our FY18 pax forecast of
132.4m vs current guidance for 130m, the key months to support or challenge this view will
be over the Q218 quarter to end September. We rate these stats as neutral.

BE12:01pm

Goodbody again.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Oh, and I flew Norwegian a month or two ago. They were excellent! Like, civilised. And absurdly cheap.

BE12:02pm

They must be losing craploads of money.

BE12:02pm

(Not investment advice.)

12:02 pm
undefined
BE12:03pm

Grey on Acal full-years requested. Happy to help.

Acal PLC (ACL:LSE): Last: 302.00, up 10 (+3.42%), High: 305.75, Low: 282.00, Volume: 71.36k
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Peel Hunt.

BE12:04pm

FY17 PBT came in a nudge ahead of our (and consensus)
forecast at £17.2m after a year that was characterised very
clearly by two distinct halves. After a very tough first half, H2
saw organic underlying growth of 6% and momentum has
continued into FY18e. This morning we are increasing our TP to
360p from 315p and reiterate our Buy recommendation.

BE12:04pm

FY17 adj PBT was £17.2m vs PHe (and consensus) £17.1m, on revenues +18%
(-1% underlying organic at CER) to £338.2m but this was very clearly a year of
2 halves: H2 underlying organic growth was +6%. In addition, the order book at
end of Mar was +13% organic, and we understand momentum has continued
into Q1 of FY18E. This has been driven by an increase in new project activity as
well a good level of repeat business, as well as cross-selling and a good
performance from recent acquisitions.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Upgrades. it’s early in the year, but given the small FY17 beat and the strong
start to FY18, we are nudging our forecasts up accordingly. Our FY18E PBT and
EPS increase 2% to £21.1m and 21.7p respectively.
Reiterate Buy. H2 has come through as the order book had indicated and should
prove a robust reminder of the ever-improving quality of the business and the
long-term investment case for Acal – to grow and develop a higher margin, high
quality business by organic growth supplemented by acquisitions, capitalising on
its unique position to consolidate a highly fragmented market. Taking into
account the strength of the end markets as we head into FY18, the strength of the
balance sheet and scope for further acquisitions, and the upgrades, we are raising
our TP to 360p which equates to what we think is an undemanding PER of
16.5x our revised Mar18E EPS. With 20% upside we reiterate our Buy
recommendation.

BE12:04pm

Stifel cover too, I think. One moment.

BE12:05pm

This was very much a tale of two halves for Acal with a very strong 2H. The
group enters FY18 with confidence supported by a good order book (+22%).
Cash generation surprises to the upside with balance sheet gearing coming
down to 1.2x from 1.7x. We continue to argue that the group’s strong
fundamentals are not discounted in the rating. BUY.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

And FinnCapppppp

BE12:06pm

Acal has reported FY 2017 adj. EPS up +13% (our forecast 11%) driven by H2 organic sales growth of +6% (up from a -7% decline in H1), a continued rise in margins, a strong contribution from acquisitions and favourable FX translation. Cash flow was also strong with pre-exceptional operating cash conversion of 151%. With the year-end order book up +22% CER (+13% organically) the outlook remains positive. We make no changes to our PBT/EPS forecasts and reiterate our view that Acal has the market opportunity and services to build a significantly larger business.

undefined
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

ROTR, why would Amazon want to spin off anything?

BE12:06pm

Is there an argument that it's undervalued on a SOTP basis?

BE12:08pm

Bezos is building a nation state, not a company. Why voluntarily create a diaspora? And are we really imagining that any antitrust authority will have a grip on Amazon's business sufficient to tear it apart?

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

@Lefevre: yes, agree. Though if look at Microsoft regulation over the past couple of decades.

BE12:10pm

Browser wars, for instance.

BE12:11pm

And The EU forcing that rigmarole where you have to select which dialup ISP you wanted to use from lists baked into the Windows XP install disk.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Is that the reason you don't use Bing? I doubt it.

BE12:12pm

Anyway, have some Amazon SOTP from JP Morgan.

BE12:12pm

We believe Amazon is well positioned as the market leader in
eCommerce, where it’s still early days with US eCommerce representing ~12% of
adjusted retail sales (ex-gas, food, and autos), which we view as likely going to
30%+ over time. We believe Amazon continues to show strong ability to take share
of overall eCommerce, and its flexibility in pushing first-party vs. third-party
inventory and its Prime offering both serve as major advantages. Additionally, we
believe AWS is the leader in the public cloud with a ~75% US market share, and it
remains early with only ~10% of workloads in the cloud today and the pace of cloud
adoption accelerating in our view. High AWS profitability gives us increased
confidence in the business and also drives a meaningful increase in our sum-of-the-
parts valuation.

12:12 pm
BE12:13pm

Our Dec 2017 price target of $1,110 is based on a sum-of-the-parts analysis as we
believe this methodology appropriately attributes value to the company’s large, fast-
growing, and profitable AWS segment, in which Amazon continues to invest.
We apply a 0.75x multiple on 2018E North America and International GMV of
$473B, which we believe is justified as large retailer peer WMT trades at ~0.5x
GMV and as Amazon has a meaningfully higher growth profile. We apply a 14x
multiple on our 2018E AWS EBITDA of ~$12B, which is at a discount to other SaaS
companies such as Salesforce (currently trading at ~22x CY2018E EBITDA).

BE12:13pm

BE12:13pm

Blimey, we cover some diverse ground here, don't we?

12:13 pm
BE12:14pm

Though for today, we're done.

BE12:14pm

Thanks for sticking around for the last hour or so.

BE12:14pm

RBS settlement story went live a few moments ago: https://www.ft.com...-bea3-7524954f49b2

12:15 pm
BE12:15pm

A group representing thousands of Royal Bank of Scotland shareholders has finally settled with the bank over its 2008 share sale, which means former chief executive Fred Goodwin will not face a court hearing.

A spokesperson for the RBS Shareholder Action Group said that it has “accepted legal advice and the matter will not now go to court”.

European sales grew 52.3% on a constant currency basis to £71.5m, despite management taking a more measured approach to promotional and marketing activity. AO has thus far been successful in translating its strong customer service focused approach in Continental Europe, however there is a necessity to build volumes and sales with a long term target of c€250m of revenue by FY2021.

Management has highlighted that the challenging backdrop in the electricals market has continued into FY2018, outlining that macroeconomic factors from the comparable period in FY2017 are likely to lead to a slower growth rate in the first quarter of the FY2018 for UK trading. At this moment we do not anticipate any significant changes to our FY2018 estimates, however we await further guidance upon the completion of the analyst presentation later today.
